message: NA
NA
I was honored to be sworn in to the 115th Congress yesterday. I am excited and ready to get to work on behalf of the people of Wyoming!
Pleased to announce staff assignments, office locations and first committee appointment.  https://cheney.house.gov/media/press-releases/liz-cheney-sworn-wyoming-s-representative
https://cheney.house.gov/media/press-releases/congressman-cheney-speaks-importance-ending-out-control-federal-regulation

On National Law Enforcement Day -- and every day -- we should respect and honor the brave men and women who put their lives on the line every day to keep us safe. Our local law enforcement and first responders deserve our gratitude and respect for always moving swiftly toward danger, and for taking action to protect life.  For years, President Obama has ignored calls by law enforcement officials to light the White House in blue in honor of first responders who have made the ultimate sacrifice. Today is a great day for our outgoing president to honor these requests as a show of thanks for our detectives, troopers and sheriffs for their courage.

Wyoming should be able to manage the gray wolf without outside interference. This bill will stop the "management by litigation" culture that has done so much damage to our state.  https://cheney.house.gov/media/press-releases/congressman-cheney-introduces-legislation-delist-gray-wolf-believes-most

It was great to visit with new Gillette City Council Member Shay Lundvall and Tyler Miller & E.O. Sowerwin from Eathwork Solutions in Gillette. Earthworks is a terrific WYO company helping to make our roads safer and creating jobs.

The Cheyenne Regional Medical Center began as a tent hospital erected by the Union Pacific Railroad in 1867 to treat workers who built the transcontinental railroad. Today, CRMC Center celebrates 150 years of service to the community of Laramie County.  I congratulate CRMC for their hard work and dedication in providing health care to the people of Wyoming.

For eight years, the Obama Administration has targeted and attempted to undermine the constitutional rights of gun owners. This legislation will help protect our individual constitutional right to keep and bear arms by ensuring that law-abiding citizens with concealed carry permits will enjoy reciprocity in other states.  https://cheney.house.gov/media/press-releases/congressman-cheney-cosponsors-concealed-carry-reciprocity-act

I'm honored to be able to serve the people of Wyoming on these important committees where we can begin to undo the damage of the last eight years, bring economic growth and jobs back to Wyoming, and ensure we do everything necessary to keep America safe.  https://cheney.house.gov/media/press-releases/congressman-liz-cheney-announces-committee-assignments-115th-congress

Today, I voted for beginning the process of repealing and replacing Obamacare.   Obamacare has resulted in increased costs for patients, skyrocketing premiums, less consumer choice in healthcare, lower quality of care and lost jobs. In Wyoming and all across the country, people need relief from the trainwreck of Obamacare. I am proud that one of my first votes in Congress was to start the process to repeal and replace this failed system. The people of Wyoming deserve healthcare that puts patients and their families in the driver's seat. Individuals, not government bureaucrats, should be in charge of their own healthcare decisions. Today, we took the first important step in that direction.
Working hard with my team in Cheyenne. Our offices are open and ready to help.  For more information on the location of my offices, go to my webpage: cheney.house.gov

Barack Obama has chosen to end his presidency the same way he began it-- aiding America's enemies.  My full statement here: https://cheney.house.gov/media/press-releases/congressman-cheney-statement-manning-commutation-and-obama-guantanamo-releases
It was terrific to have the chance to hear from so many people at our open house in Casper yesterday.

Congratulations to President Trump. It was an honor to celebrate the Inauguration of President Donald Trump alongside Brian Mast (FL-18) and Scott Taylor (VA-02). Congressman Mast and Congressman Taylor have both served in our Armed Forces.  Today, more than ever, is a reminder of how lucky we are to live in this great country and honor those who serve.
“but many seemed to agree that Cheney was the real fashion icon of the day.”  Totally agree.  Like if you agree!    http://heatst.com/politics/dick-cheney-cowboy-hat/

It was great to be in Casper last week. I had the chance to sit down with Aaron Groff at KTWO to discuss getting to work on behalf of the people of Wyoming. We talked repealing and replacing Obamacare, rolling back regulation, and bringing jobs back to Wyoming.  http://k2tv.com/news.php?id=7366

I am proud to introduce legislation with Senator Enzi and Senator Barrasso that will ensure more of the precious water coming from the Fontenelle Reservoir can be stored and used by our farmers, ranchers and local communities.

Today, I introduced legislation in the House of Representatives, under the Congressional Review Act (CRA), to block implementation of the BLM’s Planning 2.0 rule.  Planning 2.0, implemented in the waning days of the Obama Administration, undermines local land management, dilutes the authority of our county commissioners, and opens up the possibility that foreign non-governmental organizations would have input in Wyoming’s land use management planning process.
It was great to join John Birbari, where we discussed legislation I have introduced in the House to rein-in BLM by repealing Planning 2.0.
In Case You Missed It http://www.gillettenewsrecord.com/news/wyoming/article_afee2bfe-6c69-5467-938b-837edfe0f8ab.html

I was proud to introduce this legislation and work with my colleagues to secure its passage in the House today. Repealing BLM 2.0 will help ensure the voices of Wyoming citizens and our local elected leaders are heard. I look forward to continuing to work to repeal regulations that stand in the way of economic growth and job creation. In Wyoming, we know that citizens in our local communities and our elected officials are the best stewards of our land and resources. Repeal of BLM 2.0 will help restore authority where it belongs - to our states and local communities.  https://cheney.house.gov/media/press-releases/us-house-passes-resolution-introduced-congressman-cheney-blocking

“Congressman Liz Cheney of Wyoming deserves a great deal of credit for her leadership on this issue, and we call on the Senate to follow suit and approve Sen. Lisa Murkowski’s (R-Alaska) companion resolution as soon as possible,” Lane said  I was honored to work with groups like the National Cattlemen’s Beef Association, the Public Lands Council and especially groups from my home state including the Wyoming Association of Conservation Districts, Wyoming County Commissioners Association, Wyoming Farm Bureau Federation and Wyoming Stock Growers Association, the Wyoming Wool Growers Association, Petroleum Association of Wyoming,  Governor Matt Mead to ensure the House passage of a resolution that will repeal the Bureau of Land Management’s (BLM’s) Planning 2.0 Rule.  #teameffort  http://kticradio.com/agricultural/a-huge-victory-cattlemen-hail-u-s-house-passage-of-resolution-to-repeal-blms-planning-2-0-rule/
Congratulations to Sierra White for winning the Wyoming Boys and Girls Club Youth of the Year Award.

We will be hosting office hours in Buffalo today with members of Senator Enzi and Senator Barrasso’s staff.  Office Hours will start 11:00 am at the Buffalo Library.  We are here to help so please stop by!

It was great to spend some time last week with the tremendous Americans serving our nation at F.E. Warren in Cheyenne.  The 90th Missile Wing plays a critical role in defending our nation.  I am proud of the work these fine men and women are doing here in Wyoming to protect and defend us all.

It was wonderful to meet Susan Fessler of Lander and Priscilla Dowse of Casper. I appreciate all the hard work that they do on behalf of Special Olympics for Wyoming and nationwide. Susan brought back the gold and other medals from the 2014 Special Olympics in cycling.  Her grit and determination is an inspiration to us all.

It was great to meet with and discuss public lands and infrastructure needs with the Grand Teton Association yesterday.  Grand Teton National Park is one of the many treasures of our state and I look forward to continuing to work with the Grand Teton Association.

Phil and I were saddened to hear about the passing of Congressman John Wold. John was a true inspiration and leader for Wyoming for more than 60 years. As a World War II veteran, U.S. Congressman, philanthropist, entrepreneur and member of the Wyoming House of Representatives, John's life epitomized service. He was a role model for us all and he made our state a better place. Our thoughts and prayers are with the entire Wold family.

I welcome today's ruling by the Tenth Circuit overturning the EPA's determination that redrew the boundaries of our state. As in many other instances, the EPA had overstepped its authority on this matter and today's Tenth Circuit ruling corrects that.
It was great meeting with Gillette Mayor Louise Carter-King and her terrific team. I look forward to working together for Gillette and Campbell County.

My office will be hosting office hours in Fremont County next week with members of Senator Enzi and Senator Barrasso’s staff. Office hours will start at 9:00 am in Shoshoni, 11:00 am in Riverton and 2:00 pm in Lander. Our office is here to help so please stop by!

Thanks very much to Campbell County Health Board for hosting a roundtable earlier this week on health care reform.  It was great to have the opportunity to discuss how we can fix our broken health care system in a way that benefits the citizens of Wyoming.
It was an honor to address the Wyoming Legislature this morning.  I am grateful for their hard work on behalf of all of us.
I always appreciate the opportunity to visit KGWN in Cheyenne. I enjoyed discussing the repeal of BLM Planning 2.0 with Mariah Ellis.

My office will be hosting office hours in Big Horn County on Thursday with members of Senator Enzi and Senator Barrasso's staff. Office hours will start at 1:30 in Cowley and at 3:00 pm in Lovell. My office is here to help so please stop by!
It was great to hold my first Wyoming Wednesday this morning with Senator Enzi and Senator Barrasso. Here we are with some of Wyoming’s finest County Commissioners.

I enjoyed meeting with Bruce Eldredge from the Buffalo Bill Center of the West in Cody and Katy Lewis and Katie March of the Colorado-Wyoming Association of Museums this week.  They do terrific work on behalf of Wyoming museums.

I was happy to see Secretary Zinke rescind the Obama-era Fish and Wildlife Service's rule on the use of lead ammunition and fishing sinkers on public lands. Read my full statement: https://goo.gl/YMXagf

I join Senator Enzi and Senator Barrasso in applauding the federal appeals court decision today to remove the gray wolf from the endangered species list in Wyoming. This ruling puts the process of managing our gray wolf populations back where it belongs- in Wyoming’s capable hands. Read our full statements here: https://goo.gl/BQViC2

It was wonderful to see our friend Jim Magagna of the Wyoming Stock Growers Association. Jim and I were able to discuss the repeal of BLM Planning 2.0, the delisting of the Gray Wolf and the withdrawing of the Waters of the US Rule.

I was honored to introduce H.J. Res. 44 repealing BLM Planning 2.0 in the House and I am pleased that it passed the Senate today. Planning 2.0 was a misguided attempt by the Obama administration to undermine the rights of state and local governments to manage resources and land use inside their own communities. Read my full statement here: https://goo.gl/0N1D2c

I am pleased to announce office hours in Crook County on Tuesday, March 14th. Jackie King, my deputy state director, and members of Senator Enzi and Senator Barrasso’s team will be in Moorcroft at 9:00am, Pine Haven at 10:30am and Sundance at 3:30pm.
I enjoyed meeting with Mason from Cody. I appreciate all the hard work he is doing on behalf of the Arthritis Foundation.
Congratulations to Sakiusa Meador of Sublette County for winning Wyoming’s new state Spelling Bee in Laramie. Good luck at the Scripps National Spelling Bee, I look forward to cheering you on!

Congratulations to Cody Senior Jessica Morales for being named Wyoming’s student Journalist of the Year. It’s great to see the hard work and dedication of Wyoming’s students pay off. Good luck in Seattle, we’ll be rooting for you!

Yesterday, the House passed legislation that I introduced to approve an expansion in water storage for the Fontenelle Reservoir in Lincoln County. I am pleased that this project, which has been tied up in endless D.C. red tape for years will now go to the Senate. Read my full statement here: https://goo.gl/BmFU3l

I am pleased to announce office hours in Lincoln County on Thursday, March 23rd. Karmen Rossi from my office along with members of Senator Enzi and Senator Barrasso’s team will also be in Star Valley Ranch starting at 10:15 am.

My prayers go out to the victims of the horrific terrorist attack in London today.  We stand shoulder to shoulder with our closest ally, the United Kingdom, and all other members of the civilized world in our commitment to defeating radical Islamic terrorism.

I am proud to see H.J. Res 44, overturning BLM Planning 2.0., signed into law today by President Trump. I introduced this legislation and was proud to work with Senator Lisa Murkowski (R-AK) and Wyoming's Senators Enzi and Barrasso to see it pass both chambers. The rule we overturn today would have had far reaching and damaging implications on public lands and our economy in Wyoming.  Planning 2.0 would have given the federal government and radical environmental groups control over land use and resource planning in our state, at the expense of local officials and stakeholders.
I enjoyed being in Sundance this weekend and welcomed the chance to spend time with our terrific Crook County Commissioners: Kelly Dennis, Jeanne Whalen and Steve Stahla.

Announcing office hours in Converse and Niobrara Counties on Thursday, March 30th. Jackie King, my deputy state director, and members of Senator Enzi and Senator Barrasso’s team will be in Glenrock at 9:00 am, Douglas at 10:30 am and Lusk at 3pm.

Announcing office hours in Weston County on Friday, March 31st. Jackie King, my deputy state director, and members of Senator Enzi and Senator Barrasso’s team will be in Newcastle at 10 am and Upton at 2:30 pm.

I welcome the important steps taken today by President Trump to terminate some of the Obama administration's devastating energy policies. I look forward to continuing my work with Wyoming’s delegation and my colleagues in the House and Senate to provide much-needed relief from strangling regulations. We will work every day to unleash the potential of our fossil fuel industries which support our freedom, our people, our jobs, our resources, and our way of life. Read my full statement here: https://goo.gl/HSA59V”
It was great to be able to meet with Mayor Paul Brooks and City Clerk Kathy Lenz this past weekend in Sundance. I appreciate all of the hard work they are doing.

Today, I joined Secretary Zinke as he signed orders repealing burdensome and unnecessary Obama-era energy regulations. The orders signed this morning will be crucial in unleashing Wyoming’s energy industry and creating a new era in energy production. Secretary Zinke ended the moratorium on coal leases on federal lands, implemented an agency review of mitigation and climate change policies and established a Royalty Policy Committee. Wyoming’s fossil fuel industry is crucial in ensuring people all across our country have access to reliable and affordable energy. I will continue to work with President Trump, Secretary Zinke and my colleagues in Congress to reverse these devastating regulations and bring energy jobs and growth back to Wyoming .

It was wonderful to sit down and talk with UW President Laurie Nichols, Dr. Jean Garrison, Ben Blalock and Paula Lutz from the University of Wyoming. I am grateful for their hard work on behalf of our students. Go Pokes!

It was great to be able to visit with a stellar bunch of 4-H kids from across Wyoming. The dedication and hard work that these students are putting in will pay off. I enjoyed talking with this impressive group of Wyoming's future leaders.
I enjoyed meeting with Collette, Cole, Jan and Mary Lynne from Powell, Casper and Cheyenne. We were able to discuss the important role that Wyoming Community Health Centers play across our state.

Last week, I introduced legislation to make sure that no future moratorium on coal leasing on federal lands can be imposed without congressional approval. Obama-era energy policies focused on destroying our fossil fuel industry, killing jobs and devastating communities across Wyoming. Our fossil fuel industry provides power, jobs and economic growth in Wyoming and all across the country. Read my full statement here: https://goo.gl/j6QROr

It was wonderful to be able to spend some time speaking with the Wyoming Stock Growers and Wool Growers Associations. Wyoming’s agriculture industry is critical to our state’s economy and our way of life. I will continue fighting for Wyoming’s farmers and ranchers every day.
I commend President Trump for his justified and decisive action against Syria. He sent an important message to the world that America is back.

When Justice Antonin Scalia passed away last year, the country lost more than a brilliant jurist. We lost an American hero and one of the greatest Supreme Court Justices in history. President Trump deserves credit for honoring his commitment to voters by nominating Neil Gorsuch to take Justice Scalia's place.  Justice Gorsuch possesses a record of integrity, impartiality, and fidelity to the Constitution, and he will do an exceptional job serving the American people on the U.S. Supreme Court.
It was wonderful to be with the Sublette County Commissioners in Pinedale yesterday. Andy Nelson, Joel Bousman, David Burnett and Mack Rawhouser are doing a great job for Sublette County.

Thanks to Wally Johnson and the rest of the Sweetwater County Commissioners for inviting me to speak at their meeting in Rock Springs. It was good to be able to hear more about some local projects and all that they are doing in Sweetwater County.
It’s always a pleasure to join Al Harris and his grandson on Sweetwater Now.
I enjoyed sitting down with Gregory Hasman at the Rocket Miner in Rock Springs to discuss my first couple of months in Congress.

There is no better place to enjoy the bounty of our lands than in Wyoming- and there is no better time to celebrate them than #NationalParkWeek. We are blessed in Wyoming to have so many beautiful National Parks. Admission is free on April 22nd and 23rd, so be sure to get outside, explore this uniquely American treasurers and #FindYourPark. https://findyourpark.com

It was great to spend some time with Iain Woessner at the Rawlins Daily Times, where we discussed my legislation repealing BLM Planning 2.0, unrolling burdensome federal regulations and simplifying the tax structure to benefit small businesses. Always great to be back in Rawlins!

Millions of Americans rely on Wyoming’s fossil fuels for their electricity. The Obama Administration’s MATS rule was an attempt to destroy the industry. This harmful and unnecessary rule should be repealed, Congress and the administration must continue to roll back regulations that destroy jobs and increase energy prices on American families and businesses. Full article here: https://goo.gl/h0JYCr.

It was great to be able to tour the refinery in Sinclair and hear about all the advancements in technology and safety that they are doing. Sinclair provides over 564 jobs here in Carbon County. Since starting in Washington I have been fighting every day to roll back unnecessary and job killing regulations that harm our energy industries in Wyoming. Thank you to Steve and Charles for leading the tour!
Always fun to be on with Aaron Groff at K2TV in Casper. We discussed the repeal of Obamacare, cost of rural healthcare and legislation that I introduced prohibiting future coal moratoriums.
ICYMI: My recent sit-down with the Rawlins Daily Times.

It was an honor to be able to address the Wyoming Association of Rural Waters in Casper. I was happy that we had the chance to discuss the Endangered Species Act Reform, WOTUS repeal and NEPA reform. A big thank-you to Mark Pepper, Loran Crain, Chuck McVey and all who came out

Today’s final action taken by the Circuit Court of Appeals in Washington D.C. is welcome news to Wyoming’s ranchers, sportsmen, and outfitters, but also serves as a reminder that state agencies are in the best position to manage wildlife. I look forward to continuing my work in Congress to ensure species population management in Wyoming is conducted in a way that serves the best interests of our state. Read my full statement here:

I enjoyed taking questions and meeting with representatives from the American Council of Snowmobile Associations from Cody, Rock Springs and Cheyenne. We had a great discussion focused on recreation, public land management policy and transportation priorities for Wyoming.

It was great to meet with students from Guernsey, Wheatland and Riverton on the Capitol steps. I enjoyed our discussion and questions on voting cards, upcoming legislation in Congress and my work on the Natural Resources, Rules, and Armed Services Committees.

I was pleased to have the opportunity to meet with folks from Wyoming who are working hard to help provide mosquito nets to areas of the world that are suffering from outbreaks of malaria. I wish them the best of luck in their upcoming rock-paper-scissors tournament fundraiser in Casper to raise money for additional mosquito nets.
Announcing office hours in Albany County on Tuesday, May 2nd. Karmen Rossi, from my office, and members of Senator Enzi and Senator Barrasso’s team will be in Laramie starting at 1:30 pm.

It was a pleasure to welcome co-op directors from the Wyoming Rural Electric Association. We discussed numerous issues including legislation I have cosponsored that would expedite the removal of vegetation on power lines that have led to outage increases across Wyoming.

One of my favorite activities in Washington, is having the opportunity to welcome and spend time with students from Wyoming. This week Senator Enzi, Senator Barrasso and I met with the We the People teams from Sheridan High School and Jackson Hole High School. These impressive students were in town to represent our state at the National Finals Competition and Conference.  Congratulations to both schools on their hard work and for asking such wonderful questions.

In the aftermath of eight years of Obama-era policies, the United States military is facing a potentially devastating readiness, manpower and modernization crisis. At the same time, threats to our security are grave and growing. For too long, we have failed to provide our men and women in uniform with the resources they need to defend the nation. President Trump requested $30 billion in supplemental funding to begin to undo the damage. Though the actual supplemental funding needed was significantly higher, the omnibus spending bill provided only $15 billion, half the amount requested by the President. I could not support legislation that provided wholly inadequate funding to begin to rebuild America's military. As elected representatives of the American people, we have no more important or sacred obligation than providing for the common defense. If we fail to provide the resources necessary to defend our nation, nothing else we do will matter.
Read my full statement on the passage of the American Health Care Act (AHCA).
I appreciated the opportunity to discuss my vote repealing Obamacare on KGAB with Glenn Woods.  http://kgab.com/liz-cheney-discusses-yes-vote-on-health-care-bill-video/

Honored to welcome home B Btry 2/300 WY Army National Guard in Lander today along with Governor Mead. Our troops served with distinction in Afghanistan taking the fight to the enemy & defending our freedom.

Thanks to the Fremont County Commissioners for a productive meeting today in Riverton. It was good to have a chance to discuss a wide range of issues and challenges facing our towns and communities. Thank you to the commissioners for the important work they are doing for Fremont County.
It was great to spend National Teacher's Day with teachers and students at Stocktrail and Rawhide Elementary schools in Gillette. Thanks to our teachers for all they do.
NA

It was good to visit with county commissioners in Gillette during my time in Campbell County this week. I'm glad we had a chance to discuss important work getting done in Congress addressing healthcare reform, strengthening our coal industry and rebuilding infrastructure.

It was an honor to join 2017 Jefferson Award nominees from across Wyoming at this week’s ceremony in Casper. The award recognizes the dedication of many who work each and every day to give back to our local communities. Congratulations to all of the nominees and thank you for your service.
I appreciated the opportunity to join Aaron Groff at K2TV in Casper to discuss numerous topics.

It was a great to host Wyoming Wednesday this morning with Senators Enzi and Barrasso on Capitol Hill. We were honored to be joined by Lt. Chris Hadlock who has been named as Wyoming's Peace Officer of the Year. As both a sheriff and member of the Casper Police Department, Lt. Hadlock has worked to keep our local communities safe for 27 years.
Thank you Sgt. Atkins for your service.
I enjoyed taking questions and talking with students from Cokeville High School today with Senator Enzi and Senator Barrasso.

This legislation will finally give Wyoming the 50 percent share of federal mineral royalties that we are rightfully owed under the Mineral Leasing Act (MLA). For years, the federal government has been withholding 2 percent of mineral revenues that belong to western states. The introduction of this legislation today will make Wyoming whole again and ensure that Wyoming receives our share of the mineral royalties. These funds are crucial in providing funding to communities across Wyoming. I'm proud to have introduced this bill in the House and I look forward to continuing to work with Senators Enzi and Barrasso, who introduced the bill in the Senate, to ensure that Washington no longer withholds payments that belong to Wyoming.

On Memorial Day, and every day, we pay tribute to the brave servicemen and women who have made the ultimate sacrifice for our country. We remember the Gold Star Families of our fallen heroes. We dedicate ourselves to continuing to protect and defend the freedom for which so many have died.

My statement on President Trump’s decision to withdraw from the Paris Climate Agreement.  I strongly support President Trump's decision to withdraw from the Paris Climate Agreement. This agreement imposed emissions standards that would have devastated America's fossil fuel industry with no measurable impact on the climate. The agreement was based on flawed science and its purpose was to kill our coal industry. President Trump was right to pull out of this damaging agreement. While the benefits of today's decision will continue to be felt in Wyoming in the form of increased energy development, exploration and job creation our work is not finished. We must continue our efforts to roll back disastrous policies such as the Clean Power Plan, and other components of the Obama-era war on fossil fuels that have resulted in more regulation, higher costs, and government control of our energy sector in Wyoming and across America.

Congratulations to the Wyoming Association of Municipalities on their 50th Anniversary! WAM does a terrific job of bringing together elected officials and community leaders from across our state to share ideas that help make Wyoming a wonderful place to live. I was honored to attend their opening session yesterday in Gillette.

On this day 73 years ago, more than 160,000 Allied troops landed on the beaches of Normandy to confront evil and fight for a free world. The anniversary of D-Day offers an opportunity to recognize the turning point of the war in Europe, and a time to honor all who fought and died to protect our liberty and freedom.
I'm very proud to have supported the VA Accountability Act, which passed the House yesterday. Ensuring our veterans have the care and protection they deserve is a solemn obligation of our nation.
My thoughts and prayers are with our Whip and friend Steve Scalise, staff and the heroic Capitol Police officers who were wounded this morning.

As a Member of the Natural Resources Committee, I had the privilege of introducing Jim Neiman from Hulett at last week's Federal Lands Subcommittee hearing. Jim offered testimony on topics including the mismanagement of our national forests and the need for NEPA reform. We discussed common sense solutions to improve the health of our forests. The federal government owns over 9 million acres of federal forests in Wyoming, so it is critical that they make healthy forests a priority. It was also good to have Senator Larry Hicks who represents Senate District 11 in the Wyoming legislature as well as Pat O’Toole who is a Wyoming rancher, former member of the Wyoming House of Representatives and a leader in western conservation efforts at the hearing. They were both in town from Wyoming on behalf of the Family Farm Alliance.

For years the Obama Administration failed to acknowledge the hard work and dedication of the state, tribal, and federal partners which led to the healthy recovery of the grizzly bear population inside the Greater Yellowstone Ecosystem. This welcome decision to delist the grizzly bear from the Endangered Species Act rightly returns management of the Yellowstone grizzly to where it should be, under the control of experts in Wyoming, not Washington.

Wyoming’s waters are our most important natural resource. This EPA grant recognizes that the best stewards of our waters are our state and local officials. The Wyoming Department of Environmental Quality deserves to be recognized for crafting effective, efficient and actionable watershed plans worthy of this funding that will help to improve the quality of our waters today and for generations to come.

I was proud to join Senator Enzi and Barrasso last Wednesday in awarding 24 Congressional Gold Medals to students from all across Wyoming who have earned this impressive award. Each of these winners has shown dedication to community service and improving our state. They are Wyoming's future leaders. Congratulations to all 24 Wyoming Congressional Medal winners.

I was proud to speak in the House last week in support of the Electricity Reliability and Forest Protection Act. This was legislation I cosponsored with Rep. LaMalfa that will expedite the removal of hazardous vegetation and trees that threaten power outages and costly wildfires across Wyoming.

This weekend I had the honor of attending the 99th Annual American Legion and Auxiliary Department of Wyoming Convention in Worland. I enjoyed speaking with so many brave veterans who served on behalf of our nation. Thank you for your service and for all you continue to do in supporting our local communities.

As a member of the House Armed Services Committee, I know we face a readiness crisis in our Armed Forces and an array of grave and imminent threats. Global warming is not one of them. Al Qaeda and ISIS are not launching attacks against the West because of the weather. North Korea isn't building the capability to attack the United States because it is too hot. We have a duty to ensure our military can use limited resources to defeat imminent threats. We must focus on rebuilding our military and reversing the devastating Obama-era defense cuts.

This week, I supported the No Sanctuary for Criminals Act and Kate’s Law as they passed the House. We are a nation of laws and we must ensure we enforce those laws. The No Sanctuary for Criminals Act ensures that cities and states are held to account for defying federal immigration laws. Kate's Law enhances prison sentences for illegal aliens who have previously committed crimes and then re-enter our country.
Happy July 4th  - never forget we owe our freedom to the brave men and women who serve in our Armed Forces.

Wyoming’s economy is built on access to abundant and affordable sources of energy that power America. The secretarial order by the Department of the Interior to streamline the unacceptable backlog of permit applications for mineral leases on federal lands will help to bring an end to the previous administration’s war on Wyoming jobs and fossil fuels. It’s essential for our economic and national security needs that the federal government continues to remove the regulatory burden that threatens the effective implementation of leasing programs across the West. With the federal government out of the way, Wyoming's energy industry can begin to thrive again, bringing back jobs and economic growth and ensuring our nation has access to reliable energy for generations to come.

Philip and I were honored to join Governor Mead, Senator Barrasso and Bobbi Barasso at the The Ames Monument National Historic Landmark Dedication Ceremony this morning. The Ames Monument stands at what was once the highest elevation on Union Pacific's line, Sherman Summit, at a height of 8,247 feet.  The monument, commissioned by the Union Pacific in 1897, is a testament to the grit, ingenuity and determination of the men who built the transcontinental railroad.

Congratulations to ST1 Justin Sullivan on receiving the 2017 Navy Times Service Member of the Year Award. Justin hails from Gillette and has served our country overseas in Europe as well as two combat tours in Afghanistan. He has been awarded two Presidential Volunteer Service awards and the Navy League’s Outstanding Service Member award for his work volunteering in local communities. He spends countless hours teaching teenagers and students about leadership, community service and the importance of the Navy.  ST1 Sullivan makes Wyoming proud.  I was honored to stand by his side as he received this well deserved award.  To learn more about Justin click here: http://www.militarytimes.com/video/st1-justin-sullivan-navy-service-member-of-the-year.

This afternoon, I joined Senator Enzi and Senator Barrasso in welcoming Boy Scout troops from all across Wyoming to the U.S. Capitol. We were pleased to be able to talk with them about the skills they are gaining through scouting. Each of the scouts came ‘prepared’ with good questions about our work in Washington and important issues. With troops from all across the state, including Sheridan, Evanston, Rock Springs, Cokeville, Lyman and Mountain View, Wyoming was well-represented by many future leaders and Eagle Scouts from the Boy Scouts of America.

I spoke with the Free Beacon this week about the critical need for Congress to provide our military with the resources they need to defend us. To do this, we must repeal the Budget Control Act. Providing for the defense of our nation is the most important constitutional responsibility of the U.S. Congress.   Nothing else we do will matter if we fail to get this right.

The Juvenile Diabetes Research Foundation hosts a Children's Congress every two years in Washington where kids living with type 1 diabetes gather from across the country. Today, I was able to meet with Casey Prior from Sheridan, Cash Halpin from Jackson and members of their families to talk about their advocacy work.

The grizzly bear delisting marks the culmination of many years of hard work between tribal, state and federal partners that led to a recovery of the grizzly population in the Greater Yellowstone Ecosystem. The action also confirms once again that those closest to our wildlife in Wyoming are the best suited to manage it. Too often the Endangered Species Act has been used by the federal government and radical environmentalists as a tool to block economic activities, job creation, energy production, and effective local wildlife management. I look forward to continuing the fight in Congress to reform the ESA so it works for our lands and our people.

The Natural Resources subcommittee on Energy and Mineral Resources held a hearing examining HR 1778, legislation I sponsored that would prohibit future coal moratoriums without congressional approval. Coal is a national treasure and provides jobs and economic growth across Wyoming. I was pleased to welcome Travis Deti, Executive Director of the Wyoming Mining Association, to testify on the impact that this legislation would have on our great state.

Boys and Girls Nation is a great program that teaches students about the critical importance of our government and leadership. It was a pleasure to meet with representatives of this year’s Wyoming Boys and Girls Nation from Rock Springs, Buford and Cheyenne.
I enjoyed talking with the Wyoming Wool Growers Association at their annual conference with Senator Enzi and Senator Barrasso.

The House recently passed legislation to impose sanctions on Russia, Iran and North Korea. It is critical that we hold these nations accountable for their actions and aggression. These sanctions are a necessary and important response.

The 2018 NDAA is critical to fulfilling President Trump’s promise to rebuild our military and modernize our defense capabilities. I was proud to talk about my work on the House Armed Services Committee with Arno Rosenfeld about the crucial role that this legislation will play in supporting the missions that our service men and women do every day.

Wyoming Powder River Basin coal is the best in the world. I agree that utilizing our coal is a matter of national security and ensures the reliability of the power grid. A policy that uses taxpayer dollars to advantage eastern coal over our western coal does not serve that purpose. Such a policy would be flat wrong, unjust, bad economic policy, and would be adopting the worse tactics of the Obama era when the government wasted billions of taxpayer dollars attempting to pick winners and losers and undermine the market. What we need is continued regulatory and other relief by Congress and President Trump in support of our fossil fuel industry and our free markets.
My prayers go out to victims of #Charlottesville domestic terror attack. Vile white supremacist/neo-Nazi hatred has no place in America.‬
I welcome President Trump's comments at the White House this morning, and his determination to ensure the perpetrators are brought to justice.

I’m proud to stand with Senators Enzi and Barrasso to fight against policies that would advantage eastern coal at the expense of Wyoming Powder River Basin coal. Wyoming's coal is the best, cleanest burning coal in the world. We should be working to eliminate distortions in our energy market, not imposing new ones. We know that the most effective way to help our coal miners in Wyoming and across America is to continue eliminating the strangling regulatory burden of the Obama years as we adopt policies that ensure we can utilize our fossil fuels, which are a national treasure.

I was pleased to join Aaron Groff at K2TV in Casper for an important conversation about the threat posed to our nation by North Korea, my recent work as a member of the House Armed Services Committee to amend and pass the National Defense Authorization Act, and what I view as a harmful proposal by the Governor of West Virginia that would advantage eastern coal over Wyoming coal.

Deregulation of our fossil fuel industry and ensuring a fair market for Powder River Basin coal is a matter of national security and ensures the strong reliability of the power grid. Proposals that use taxpayer dollars to advantage eastern coal over our cleaner western coal are wrong and do not serve these purposes. I’m pleased to stand with Wyoming workers, industry and our federal delegation in encouraging the Trump administration and Congress to harness the power of the free market and continue efforts that roll back costly and burdensome regulations.
Here is the link to my full statement on President Trump's Afghanistan speech:   https://cheney.house.gov/media/press-releases/congressman-liz-cheney-s-statement-president-trumps-afghanistan-strategy

Congratulations to Jill Blazovich of Rock Springs on being named Wyoming Agriculture in the Classroom 2017 Educator of the Year. Jill, a 2nd grade teacher at Desert View Elementary in Rock Springs, has been instrumental in developing lesson plans that teach students about Wyoming's resources and stewardship. It was my honor to present Jill with her award. I join with Senators Enzi and Barrasso in congratulating the 2017 AG Hall of Fame Award recipients Peter John Camino and Keith Greis. It was great to be part of the celebration of our Wyoming Agriculture Hall of Fame 25th anniversary. Congratulations to Jill, Peter and Keith on all their work to strengthen our ag industry and our local communities.

I enjoyed being able to sit down with Greg Johnson of the Gillette News Record last week while I was in Campbell County.  We discussed the critical importance of repealing and replacing Obamacare healthcare, as well as the delegation's work on behalf of our Powder River Basin coal, the best in the world.

I enjoyed joining Senators Enzi and Barrasso at the Casper Chamber of Commerce "State of Nation" event. It was great to be able to take questions and talk about the work being done in Washington to repeal burdensome regulations, and pass pro-growth legislation to get our economy growing again. Photo credit Aaron Groff- K2TV).

I voted no today on the Debt Ceiling increase/CR/Harvey package. Here's my full statement:  https://cheney.house.gov/media/press-releases/congressman-cheneys-statement-continuing-resolutiondebt-ceiling-increase-vote

I'm proud to be a sponsor of the Federal Lands Freedom Act. The people of Wyoming are best suited to manage the oil and gas development on federal lands in our state. Wyoming is being put at a competitive disadvantage by unnecessary federal regulation which has caused multiple years of project delays. This includes BLM's inability to process requests associated with projects on federal land in a timely fashion. This legislation will help break down the federal government's one-size-fits-all approach to energy regulatory processes.   Read more about the bill below:

I was pleased to sit down and talk with Secretary of Agriculture Perdue yesterday morning. We discussed a wide range of issues that are crucial to Wyoming's agriculture community, as well as our national forests.

We encourage everyone to read President Donald Trump's address to the United Nations on Tuesday. He reiterated his commitment to rebuilding America's military, including allocating $700 billion for defense for FY 2018. He also made clear the United States will work with our allies to defend ourselves against threats from dangerous regimes like North Korea and Iran, and he challenged the United Nations to live up to the ideals behind its founding, pointing out that it has too often fallen far short of those goals.   "The united states of America has been among the greatest forces for good in the history of the world and the greatest defenders of sovereignty, security and prosperity for all."

I was pleased to join Aaron Brown of KGWN to talk about my actions in Congress for Wyoming. We discussed work we are doing in the House Resources committee, including bills I sponsored that would prohibit judicial review of the Grey Wolf delisting, uphold our Second Amendment rights, and ensure our sportsmen have access to our public lands. We also discussed work I am doing with the Forest Service and BLM to make sure Wyoming and our interests are protected.   Watch Below:
Shanah Tovah! Wishing all who celebrate Rosh Hashanah a happy, healthy, and peaceful new year.

Secretary of Interior Ryan Zinke issued a memo instructing land managers and superintendents to use their full authority to clear the dead trees and brush that fuels wildfires on federal lands in Wyoming. For the first time in 20 years, the Trump Administration will proactively work to prevent forest fires that have severely impacted Wyoming and its surrounding states instead of fighting fires after they have started. Many of these fires have been exacerbated or caused by misguided forest management policies. In recent years a large part of the Forest Service's budget has gone to fighting fires which have depleted the funds from other programs intended to prevent fires through forest restoration.

Congratulations to Tracy Ragland, Wyoming's 2017 Principal of the Year from Newcastle High School. Mr. Ragland won the award for his exemplary model of effective leadership and his commitment to ensuring each student's success. It was a pleasure getting to meet with him to discuss challenges facing our schools and our state.

Congratulations to Burlington Elementary, Sheridan Junior High, and Woodland Park Elementary in Sheridan for receiving the National Blue Ribbon Award for their excellence in academic performance. This award is a testament to the hard work put forth by the teachers, principals, families, and communities that ensured students' success in achieving their goals.

I had a great time today chatting with KGAB's Glenn Woods and taking calls from listeners. We got a chance to talk about our tax reform efforts, ongoing work to repeal and replace Obamacare and how these will affect folks in Wyoming. We also discussed the national security threats facing the United States and what we need to do to defend ourselves.

I managed the Pain-Capable Unborn Child Protection Act rule on the House Floor.  "My colleagues on the other side of the aisle claim they are committed to science, in all cases, except where it matters most, in the cases that involve the preservation of human life"  Watch Below:

Secretary of Defense Mattis and Chairman of the Joint Chiefs Dunford testified before the House Armed Services Committee. Congress cannot fulfill our most important constitutional obligation to support, raise, and maintain America's armed forces unless we repeal the Budget Control Act." “President Trump took an important step towards addressing the increasing threat of wildfires throughout the West today. The funding requested by the administration is critical to support our brave firefighters who battle wildfires in Wyoming. Congress must work to quickly pass legislation to provide the funding requested by the Trump Administration, and we must also implement the reforms called for by the President, like those in H.R. 2936, the Resilient Federal Forests Act, that will help reduce the frequency and severity of wildfires in the West.”

It was an honor to be a part of Lieutenant Colonel Jonathan F. Dryer's promotion in rank at Camp Guernsey. Lt. Col. Dryer is a highly decorated member of the armed services who served overseas in Germany and led combat missions in both Baghdad and Afghanistan. I want to thank him and his family for their service in the United States Military.

Congratulations to Wyoming's teacher of the year, Sara Reed, a kindergarten teacher at Hillcrest Elementary School in Campbell County School District #1. This award exemplifies Mrs. Reed's effort to ensure every student's needs in her classroom are met. We are proud Mrs. Reed will serve as an education ambassador for our state.

It was a pleasure to celebrate and be at the unveiling of the 150th anniversary of Sweetwater County monument. Thanks to the county commissioners and Executive Director of the Museum Brie Blasi for their hard work in ensuring we marked this important milestone for Sweetwater County. Great being with the Hole in the Wall Gang, too.

I want to thank Grand Teton National Park Superintendent David Vela for a great meeting at park headquarters. It was a terrific opportunity to discuss the issues facing one of our nation’s most beautiful national parks.

I spoke on the House floor regarding the Resilient Federal Forest Act:  “Fires are being caused and worsened by Federal mismanagement. Eight years of federal policy opposing proven methods of forest management and instead focusing on efforts to prevent all human use of our forests have done significant damage and this damage is just not to the forests that we have had to watch burn Mr. Speaker.”  Click here to read more: https://goo.gl/GciYAH

Today marks the first day of Military Family Appreciation Month, a time to recognize and celebrate the strength and support that family members provide for the men and women in uniform who protect and defend the United States. The families of our armed service members deserved to be honored for their commitment and securing a strong foundation for their families who serve the United States at home and overseas. Thank you for your dedication.

This is absolutely unacceptable, we need to repeal and replace Obamacare. Folks in Wyoming have been suffering under the high price of premiums for too long.

Today, at the Natural Resources Committee hearing I proposed an amendment that was added to the SECURE American Energy Act that clears up ambiguous language to stop burdensome regulations affecting wind turbine operators, home builders, and coal mines.  Read more here: https://goo.gl/YwFC4L
I am pleased the Senate has confirmed Mark Klaassen to serve as the U.S. Attorney for the District of Wyoming.  Read my full statement here: https://goo.gl/wmVeRj

On Veterans’ Day, and every day, we must remember the debt of gratitude we owe to the brave men and women who have served in our armed forces. Their sacrifices have preserved America's freedom. We must also make sure we provide our veterans with the care they have earned.

I encourage everyone to read this article about the need to modernize our nation’s intercontinental ballistic missiles, including those at F.E. Warren Air Force Base. We must ensure each component of the nuclear triad is modernized to ensure our nuclear deterrence is effective against the threats we face today. One of my amendments to the NDAA requires the military to maintain at least 400 ICBMs, a minimum number required to ensure adequate defenses. F. E. Warren’s missiles are a crucial piece of our national defense.   Read more below.
Check out this week's Newsletter, where I discuss my priorities for our state.  Read more here: https://goo.gl/sv8vdQ

The MBTA was created in 1918 to protect migratory bird populations from over-hunting and illegal sales but the ambiguous language of the law has been used to prevent our energy industry from engaging in lawful activities, and to delay permitting. The amendment I added to the SECURE American Energy Act clarifies the law so individuals, companies, and agencies in our state will have the benefit of knowing the law does not and was not intended to criminalize otherwise lawful activities.
Great interview from Heidi Merritt, the daughter of Hyde Merritt, a Cheyenne native who will be inducted into the National Rodeo Hall of Fame. What an incredible and well-deserved honor.
I was proud to vote for the bipartisan FY18 National Defense Authorization Act, which passed the House.  Read my full statement here: https://goo.gl/B7WfQC
I voted in favor of the Tax Cuts and Jobs Act today because it is critically important we provide tax relief for hard-working families in Wyoming.  Read my full statement here: https://goo.gl/vbBJMy
Congratulations on a great season to Wyoming's top 25 best high school football players of the year. You all earned it!

Have you signed up for my Newsletter? If not, click here to get the Newsletter delivered right to your inbox and make sure to check out my November 17th Newsletter.    Read more here: https://goo.gl/zJvwmv

My first priority will always be to support the Veterans of Wyoming and I'm proud I was able to include a provision in the House version of the NDAA to extend the ban on returning the Bells to the Philippines.

Folks in our state deserve to be in charge of the land in their own backyards. For the past eight years, the federal government's bad policies have harmed the backbone of Wyoming's economy. We need to hand more authority back to the states and the people who will serve as the best stewards of their land.

I want to thank everyone who came out for the Cheyenne Chamber of Commerce's Military Affairs Committee luncheon. It's was great to speak with all of you and take questions about the NDAA. I'm proud the NDAA is heading to President Trump's desk to be signed into law.

Congratulations to everyone who made UW's Women's Entrepreneurship Day successful and UW's College of Business Caitlyn Spradley and UW President Dr. Laurie Nichols for making wonderful opening remarks. Great job!
Wishing everyone a happy Thanksgiving. We all have so much to be grateful for and it's important we express gratitude on this special day. I hope everyone has a blessed and safe holiday.

Congratulations to the students of Rawlins Middle School, art teacher Jamie Chapman, and the Wyoming Arts Council for decorating this year's National Christmas Tree at the Capitol. I'm so proud you are representing Wyoming and can't wait to check out your handmade ornaments.
I'm happy everyone had a wonderful time at Cheyenne's Christmas Parade this weekend. It's incredible to see so many people participating in a great cause. Great job on all your hard work!

I was honored to speak at the Wyoming Natural Resources Rendezvous with Senators Enzi and Barrasso. It was great to be able to speak with over 500 ranchers about issues important facing our state's farming communities.
Thanks to all the students and teachers from Kaycee High School for stopping by to visit. It was great to get to chat with some of our state's brightest kids.

I'm pleased H.R. 1778, a bill I introduced to ensure no future moratorium on coal leasing on federal lands can be imposed without Congressional approval, passed the House Natural Resources Committee today.  Coal is a national treasure and President Obama's war on coal did real damage to the livelihoods of the people and communities in our state.  Read my full statement here: https://goo.gl/zHpkAP
Thanks to St. Stephens students for their hard work helping to clean up reservation roads.
Check out my December 1st newsletter to read more about the work I did this week for our state.  Click here to sign up and read more: https://goo.gl/itwKmy
I was pleased my bill requiring congressional approval for any future moratoriums on coal leases on federal lands passed out of Natural Resources committee this week.
I'm pleased the House passed a motion to establish a conference committee for the Republicans' tax plan, the Tax Cuts and Jobs Act tonight.  Read my statement here: https://goo.gl/XNg9ZW

I want to thank my Congressional Nomination Committee, Dr. Richard McGinity, Tucker Fagan, Heather Holbert, and Paul Cali. This weekend we had a talented group of 26 candidates apply and interview with the committee for congressional nominations to the Air Force, Navy, and Merchant Marine Academies, and to West Point. I’m grateful for the hard work and time of this impressive committee and I'm looking forward to nominating our candidates.

I support President Trump’s decision to formally recognize Jerusalem as the capital of Israel and his announcement that he will move the United States Embassy from Tel Aviv to Jerusalem. Jerusalem is the eternal and undivided capital of the state of Israel, and the United States has no closer or stronger ally than Israel.

I’m proud the House passed H.R. 38, the Concealed Carry Reciprocity Act.  Folks in Wyoming deserve to know the constitutional carry rights we enjoy at home won’t be threatened when we cross into other jurisdictions.  Read my full statement here: https://goo.gl/SQiQrs

On Pearl Harbor Remembrance Day, I had the privilege to speak on the House Floor honoring Mr. Clarence Varos, a WWII vet and Pearl Harbor survivor who will celebrate his 100th birthday this weekend.  "Mr. Varos has served our country and state in many ways. As a member of the US Navy, Mr. Varos fought through and survived the attack on Pearl Harbor. He risked his life in the defense of freedom as a gunner on the U.S.S. Hyde, transporting Marines in the Pacific theater."  Read my full statement here: https://goo.gl/VM2m1x

I'm proud President Trump signed the National Defense Authorization Act today that authorizes badly needed resources for our troops, including a long overdue and well-deserved pay raise. Congress has no higher responsibility than to provide the funding necessary for the men and women in uniform who defend our nation.  Read my full statement here: https://goo.gl/Cpxn7g
Wishing all who celebrate a blessed and peaceful eight days. From my family to yours, Happy Hanukkah.
It was an honor to celebrate WWII veteran and Pearl Harbor survivor Clarence Varos' 100th birthday this weekend. Thank you for your service and dedication to our great nation.

I want to thank everyone who attended the breakfast and Veterans meeting in Cody. It was a privilege to meet with so many who have defended our nation in the Armed Forces. I am grateful for the time they took to discuss a range of ongoing veterans issues and concerns.

Congratulations to the graduates of the Cowboy Challenge Academy and thank you to state representative Landon Brown for an inspiring commencement address. The Wyoming Cowboy Challenge Academy provides at-risk youth with the resources and learning environment for success. I'm proud of this years' graduates and excited to see what they can accomplish.
I had the great honor of meeting with Ray "Padre" Johnson, the highest decorated Navy chaplain from the Vietnam War and a celebrated painter, whose work is displayed at United Nations building.

Today the House of Representatives passed important legislation to cut taxes and simplify our out-of-date tax code.  I'm pleased Congress seized this historic opportunity to provide tax relief for Wyoming families and job creators. Allowing Wyoming families and businesses to keep more of their hard-earned money will encourage additional investment in our economy and help our local businesses expand, generating economic growth and creating new jobs for Wyoming.
